Probably the most often cited recent work on orality and writing in ancient Israel and Judah is S

Floyd criticizes Niditch’s dichotomization o f oral and written, also giving a critical history of the oral/written concept in Western thinking (‘“Write the Revelation!”^pp. 122-23). Another critic is J. Schaper, whose primary aim is to refute Niditch’s claim that Judah was primarily an oral society ("Exilic and Post-Exilic Prophecy and the Orality/Literacy Problem
He stresses the impact o f the “rise of writing
It is not always clear how Schaper distinguishes between uses of writing in general and “prophetic writing” as a distinct phenomenon

Floyd takes a critical stance to the methodologies of both Schaper and Schniedewind ("Introduction

Something of a consensus has been forming over the last couple of decades, putting emphasis on the Persian period as a formative time for the biblical writings, challenging the earlier consensus of the Persian period as a time of decline in ancient Judah. For a recent description o f this forming consensus
